title: Command: attach - Attach to tmux window
description:

title: Core: State file management and CLI skeleton
description:
## Overview
Implement the foundational infrastructure for swarm.

## Requirements
- Single Python file: `swarm.py` (zero dependencies beyond stdlib)
- State file location: `~/.swarm/state.json`
- Log directory: `~/.swarm/logs/`
- CLI skeleton using argparse with subparsers for all commands

## State File Structure
```json
{
  "workers": [
    {
      "name": "w1",
      "status": "running",
      "cmd": ["claude"],
      "started": "2024-01-10T14:30:00Z",
      "cwd": "/path/to/dir",
      "env": {"FOO": "bar"},
      "tags": ["pr-review"],
      "tmux": {"session": "swarm", "window": "w1"},
      "worktree": {"path": "/path", "branch": "work/bd-001", "base_repo": "/path"},
      "pid": null
    }
  ]
}
```

## Implementation
1. Create State class with load/save methods
2. Create ensure_dirs() for ~/.swarm and ~/.swarm/logs
3. Create main() with argparse skeleton (all subparsers, arguments per PLAN.md)
4. Add shebang and make executable

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] `python swarm.py --help` shows all commands
- [ ] `python swarm.py spawn --help` shows spawn options
- [ ] State file created on first access
- [ ] Directories created automatically

title: Command: respawn - Respawn dead workers
description:
## Overview
Implement the `swarm respawn` command to respawn a dead worker with its original command.

## Dependencies
- Depends on: swarm-szj (spawn command)

## Usage
```bash
swarm respawn <name> [options]
```

## Options
- `--clean-first` — Run clean before respawn (removes old worktree)

## Behavior
1. Read original spawn config from state
2. If `--clean-first`, clean up old worktree
3. Kill if still somehow running
4. Spawn with same options

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Reads original command from state
- [ ] Respawns with same options (tmux, worktree, env, etc.)
- [ ] --clean-first removes old worktree before respawn
- [ ] Kills worker if still running
- [ ] Error if worker not found

title: Command: interrupt and eof - Send control signals
description:
## Overview
Implement the `swarm interrupt` and `swarm eof` commands.

## Dependencies
- Depends on: swarm-1j8 (state), swarm-ljn (helpers)

## swarm interrupt
Send Ctrl-C to a worker.

```bash
swarm interrupt <name>
swarm interrupt --all
```

Behavior:
```bash
tmux send-keys -t {session}:{name} C-c
```

## swarm eof
Send Ctrl-D (EOF) to a worker. This typically exits interactive programs like claude.

```bash
swarm eof <name>
```

Behavior:
```bash
tmux send-keys -t {session}:{name} C-d
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] interrupt sends C-c to tmux window
- [ ] interrupt --all sends to all running workers
- [ ] eof sends C-d to tmux window
- [ ] Both error for non-tmux workers
- [ ] Both error for non-running workers
notes: Implementation complete. Created comprehensive test suite in test_swarm.py covering all code paths: single worker interrupt, --all flag, worker not found, non-tmux worker, not running worker, EOF command with similar validations. All 9 tests pass successfully. Implemented cmd_interrupt with --all flag support and validation (tmux worker check, running status check). Implemented cmd_eof with same validation pattern. Both functions send appropriate control signals via tmux send-keys. Code follows existing patterns in swarm.py. Syntax verified with py_compile. Files modified: swarm.py (lines 568-621), test_swarm.py (new file, 9 test cases).

title: Command: kill - Kill worker processes
description:
## Overview
Implement the `swarm kill` command to kill worker processes.

## Dependencies
- Depends on: swarm-1j8 (state), swarm-ljn (helpers)

## Usage
```bash
swarm kill <name> [options]
swarm kill --all [options]
```

## Options
- `--rm-worktree` — Also remove the git worktree
- `--all` — Kill all workers

## Behavior
1. If tmux: `tmux kill-window -t {session}:{name}`
2. If not tmux: `kill {pid}` (SIGTERM, then SIGKILL after 5s)
3. Update state to `stopped`
4. If `--rm-worktree` and worker has worktree:
   - `git worktree remove {worktree_path} --force`

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Kills tmux window for tmux workers
- [ ] Sends SIGTERM then SIGKILL for non-tmux workers
- [ ] Updates state to stopped
- [ ] --rm-worktree removes worktree
- [ ] --all kills all workers
- [ ] Error if worker not found
notes:
Implementation plan based on available helper functions:
1. Create comprehensive test suite for cmd_kill function
2. Add signal module import for SIGTERM/SIGKILL
3. Implement cmd_kill with support for single worker kill by name and --all flag
4. Tmux workers use tmux kill-window
5. Non-tmux workers use graceful shutdown with SIGTERM then SIGKILL after 5s
6. Integrate --rm-worktree flag
7. Proper error handling for missing workers
8. State management with save after updates
9. Confirmation output for killed workers
10. Run type checking and linting and ensure >90% test coverage

title: Command: logs - View worker output
description:
## Overview
Implement the `swarm logs` command to capture output from workers.

## Dependencies
- Depends on: swarm-1j8 (state), swarm-ljn (helpers)

## Usage
```bash
swarm logs <name> [options]
```

## Options
- `--history` — Include scrollback buffer (default: visible pane only)
- `--lines <n>` — Number of scrollback lines (default: 1000)
- `--follow` — Continuously poll and display (like tail -f)

## Behavior (tmux workers)
```bash
# Default
tmux capture-pane -t {session}:{name} -p

# With history
tmux capture-pane -t {session}:{name} -p -S -{lines}

# Follow (poll every 1s)
watch -n1 "tmux capture-pane -t {session}:{name} -p | tail -30"
```

## Behavior (non-tmux workers)
```bash
cat ~/.swarm/logs/{name}.stdout
# or
tail -f ~/.swarm/logs/{name}.stdout
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Shows visible pane by default (tmux)
- [ ] --history includes scrollback
- [ ] --lines controls scrollback amount
- [ ] --follow polls continuously
- [ ] Non-tmux workers read from log files
- [ ] --follow works with tail -f for non-tmux
close_reason: Implemented cmd_logs function with all required features: 1) Load state and get worker by name 2) Error handling with exit code 1 if worker not found 3) Tmux workers: default visible pane, --history includes scrollback, --follow polls every 1s 4) Non-tmux workers: default reads log file, --follow uses tail -f. Tested syntax validation and error handling successfully.

title: Command: ls - List all tracked workers
description:
## Overview
Implement the `swarm ls` command to list all tracked workers.

## Dependencies
- Depends on: swarm-1j8 (state), swarm-ljn (helpers)

## Usage
```bash
swarm ls [options]
```

## Options
- `--format <fmt>` — Output format: `table` (default), `json`, `names`
- `--status <status>` — Filter: `running`, `stopped`, `all` (default)
- `--tag <tag>` — Filter by tag

## Output Examples

**Table (default):**
```
NAME    STATUS   PID/WINDOW      STARTED   WORKTREE                  TAG
w1      running  swarm:w1        5m ago    ../swarm-worktrees/w1     pr-review
w2      running  swarm:w2        3m ago    ../swarm-worktrees/w2     pr-review
w3      stopped  -               10m ago   ../swarm-worktrees/w3     impl
```

**Names:**
```
w1
w2
w3
```

**JSON:**
```json
[{"name": "w1", "status": "running", ...}, ...]
```

## Behavior
1. Load state file
2. Refresh actual status of each worker (check tmux/pid)
3. Filter by --status and --tag if specified
4. Format and output

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Table format with proper alignment
- [ ] JSON output is valid JSON
- [ ] Names output is one per line
- [ ] Status filter works correctly
- [ ] Tag filter works correctly
- [ ] Status is refreshed from actual state (not just stored)

2. Table format implementation:

title: Command: clean - Clean up dead workers
description:
## Overview
Implement the `swarm clean` command to clean up dead workers and their worktrees.

## Dependencies
- Depends on: swarm-1j8 (state), swarm-ljn (helpers)

## Usage
```bash
swarm clean <name> [options]
swarm clean --all [options]
```

## Options
- `--rm-worktree` — Remove git worktree (default: true for clean)
- `--all` — Clean all stopped workers

## Behavior
1. Verify worker is stopped
2. If worktree exists: `git worktree remove {path} --force`
3. Remove from state.json
4. Remove log files if they exist

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Only cleans stopped workers
- [ ] Error if trying to clean running worker
- [ ] Removes worktree by default
- [ ] Removes log files
- [ ] Removes from state.json
- [ ] --all cleans all stopped workers
notes: Implementation complete. Created cmd_clean function with full TDD approach. Key changes: 1) Implemented clean command logic handling both single worker and --all flag. 2) Added status refresh before cleaning to ensure worker is stopped. 3) Handles worktree removal with rm_worktree flag (default true). 4) Removes stdout/stderr log files if they exist. 5) Removes worker from state. 6) For --all flag: skips running workers with warning. For single worker: errors if running. 7) Created comprehensive unit tests (9 test cases) covering all scenarios including edge cases. 8) Created Makefile for project with test/lint/typecheck targets. All 45 unit tests pass. Files modified: swarm.py (added cmd_clean), test_cmd_clean.py (new file with 9 tests), Makefile (new file).

title: Command: spawn - Spawn new worker processes
description:
## Overview
Implement the `swarm spawn` command to spawn new worker processes.

## Dependencies
- Depends on: swarm-1j8 (state), swarm-ljn (helpers)

## Usage
```bash
swarm spawn --name <name> [options] -- <command...>
```

## Options
- `--name <name>` — Unique identifier (required)
- `--tmux` — Run in a tmux window
- `--session <name>` — Tmux session name (default: "swarm")
- `--worktree` — Create a git worktree
- `--branch <name>` — Branch name for worktree (default: same as --name)
- `--worktree-dir <path>` — Parent dir for worktrees (default: `../swarm-worktrees`)
- `--tag <tag>` — Tag for filtering (repeatable)
- `--env KEY=VAL` — Environment variable (repeatable)
- `--cwd <path>` — Working directory

## Behavior
1. Validate name is unique (not already in state)
2. If `--worktree`:
   - Detect git repo root from cwd
   - Compute worktree path: `{worktree-dir}/{name}`
   - Run: `git worktree add {worktree_path} -b {branch}`
   - Set working directory to worktree path
3. If `--tmux`:
   - Ensure session exists
   - Create window with `tmux new-window`
   - Send command with `tmux send-keys`
4. If not `--tmux`:
   - Spawn via subprocess.Popen
   - Capture stdout/stderr to `~/.swarm/logs/{name}.stdout` and `.stderr`
   - Store PID directly
5. Record state to `~/.swarm/state.json`

## Example
```bash
swarm spawn --name w1 --tmux --worktree --branch work/bd-001 -- claude
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Non-tmux spawn works with PID tracking
- [ ] Tmux spawn creates window and runs command
- [ ] Worktree creation works
- [ ] State is persisted correctly
- [ ] Duplicate name rejected with error
notes:
Implementation complete. Files modified:
1. swarm.py - Implemented cmd_spawn() function with all required features:
   - Command parsing with leading -- strip
   - Name uniqueness validation
   - Worktree creation support
   - Environment variable parsing (KEY=VAL format)
   - Tmux and non-tmux spawn paths
   - Worker object creation and state persistence
   - Proper error handling for all edge cases

2. test_cmd_spawn.py - Created comprehensive unit tests:
   - Basic process spawn
   - Tmux spawn
   - Environment variable parsing
   - Tag assignment
   - Duplicate name rejection
   - Invalid input handling
   - All 8 tests passing

Manual testing verified:
- Basic spawn works (creates PID-based worker)
- Duplicate names properly rejected
- Environment variables correctly stored in state
- State file properly persisted to ~/.swarm/state.json

All acceptance criteria met. 28 total tests passing.

title: Command: send - Send text to tmux workers
description:
## Overview
Implement the `swarm send` command to send text to tmux-based workers.

## Dependencies
- Depends on: swarm-1j8 (state), swarm-ljn (helpers)

## Usage
```bash
swarm send <name> <text>
swarm send --all <text>
```

## Options
- `--no-enter` — Don't append Enter key after text
- `--all` — Send to all running tmux workers

## Behavior
```bash
tmux send-keys -t {session}:{name} "{text}" Enter
```

## Examples
```bash
swarm send w1 "implement the auth flow"
swarm send w1 "/review"
swarm send w1 "/pr --title 'feat: auth'"
swarm send --all "check your amail inbox"
```

## Errors
- If worker is not tmux-based, exit with error
- If worker is not running, exit with error

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Sends text to tmux window
- [ ] --no-enter skips Enter key
- [ ] --all sends to all running tmux workers
- [ ] Error for non-tmux workers
- [ ] Error for non-running workers
notes: Implementation complete. Changes: 1) Implemented cmd_send function in swarm.py with full validation (worker exists, is tmux, is running). 2) Handles --all flag to send to all running tmux workers (skips stopped workers). 3) Handles --no-enter flag. 4) Created comprehensive unit tests in test_cmd_send.py with 6 test cases covering all code paths. 5) All tests passing. 6) Python syntax check passed. Files modified: swarm.py (added cmd_send implementation), test_cmd_send.py (new file)

title: Command: wait - Wait for workers to finish
description:
## Overview
Implement the `swarm wait` command to wait for workers to finish.

## Dependencies
- Depends on: swarm-1j8 (state), swarm-ljn (helpers)

## Usage
```bash
swarm wait <name>
swarm wait --all [options]
```

## Options
- `--timeout <seconds>` — Max wait time (default: infinite)
- `--all` — Wait for all workers

## Behavior (tmux)
- Poll `tmux list-windows -t {session}` until window disappears
- Return exit code 0 when done

## Behavior (non-tmux)
- Use waitpid() or poll /proc/{pid}

## Output
```
w1: exited
w2: exited
w3: still running (timeout)
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Blocks until tmux window closes
- [ ] Blocks until process exits (non-tmux)
- [ ] Timeout works correctly
- [ ] --all waits for all workers
- [ ] Clear output showing which exited
notes: Implementation plan: 1) Import time module, 2) Implement cmd_wait with state loading, worker validation, poll loop with timeout, status refresh, and proper exit codes, 3) Write unit tests, 4) Run quality gates
